revision.comment: Moved the statement about "moko" being distinct from "tattooing" from the lede to the "Background" section, and made it clear that this refers to the *traditional* moko (using an "uhi") - because later on, the article notes that most moko today are tattoos
revision.text:
{{Use New Zealand English|date=February 2018}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''{{lang|mi|Tā moko|nocat=y}}''}} {{for|the 1 Giant Leap song "Ta Moko"|1 Giant Leap (album)}} [[File:MaoriChief1784.jpg|thumb|254px|Sketch of a Māori chief by [[Sydney Parkinson]] (1784)]] [[File:Louis John Steele - Portrait of a young Maori woman with moko - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|"Portrait of a young Maori woman with {{lang|mi|moko}}", by [[Louis John Steele]] (1891)]] [[File:Gottfried Lindauer - Tamati Waka Nene - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Portrait of [[Tāmati Wāka Nene]] by [[Gottfried Lindauer]] (1890)]] '''''{{lang|mi|Tā moko}}''''' is the permanent marking of the face and body as traditionally practised by [[Māori people|Māori]], the indigenous people of New Zealand. Captain [[James Cook]] wrote in 1769: {{quote|The marks in general are spirals drawn with great nicety and even elegance. One side corresponds with the other. The marks on the body resemble foliage in old chased ornaments, convolutions of filigree work, but in these they have such a luxury of forms that of a hundred which at first appeared exactly the same no two were formed alike on close examination.{{cite book |url=http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-RobMoko-t1-body-d1-d2.html |title=Moko; or Maori Tattooing |chapter=Moko and Mokamokai — Chapter I — How Moko First Became Knows to Europeans |page=5 |author=Major-General Robley |year=1896 |publisher=Chapman and Hall Limited |accessdate=2009-09-26 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.vanishingtattoo.com/tattoo_museum/maori_tattoos.html |title=Tattoo History Museum |publisher=vanishingtattoo.com |date= |accessdate=2009-08-24 }}}} {{lang|mi|[[Tohunga]]-tā-moko}} (tattooists) were considered ''{{lang|mi|[[tapu (Polynesian culture)|tapu]]}}'', or inviolable and sacred.{{cite web |url=http://history-nz.org/maori3.html |title=The Māori - The Tattoo (Ta Moko) }} ==Background== [[Tattoo]] arts are common in the Eastern [[Polynesia]]n homeland of Māori, and the traditional implements and methods employed were similar to those used in other parts of Polynesia.{{harvnb|Hīroa|1951|p=296}} In pre-European Māori culture, many if not most high-ranking persons received {{lang|mi|moko}}, and those who went without them were seen as persons of lower [[social status]]. Receiving {{lang|mi|moko}} constituted an important milestone between childhood and adulthood, and was accompanied by many [[rites]] and [[rituals]]. Apart from signalling status and rank, another reason for the practice in traditional times was to make a person more attractive to the opposite sex. Men generally received {{Lang|mi|moko}} on their faces, buttocks (''{{lang|mi|raperape}}'') and thighs (''{{lang|mi|puhoro}}''). Women usually wore moko on their lips (''{{lang|mi|kauwae}}'') and chins. Other parts of the body known to have moko include women's foreheads, buttocks, thighs, necks and backs and men's backs, stomachs, and calves. Historically, {{lang|mi|moko}} was distinct from [[tattoo|tattooing]], in that the skin was carved by ''{{lang|mi|uhi}}''{{cite web |url=http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/RobMoko-fig-RobMoko048a.html |title=Fig. 46.—Uhi, or chisels in the British Museum (actual size). Presented by Sir George Grey, K. C. B., &c |publisher= |accessdate=28 August 2015 }} (chisels), not punctured. This left the skin with grooves rather than a smooth surface. [[File:Korere 11.jpg|thumbnail|A collection of {{Lang|mi|korere}} (feeding funnels)]] ==Instruments used== Originally ''{{lang|mi|tohunga-tā-moko}}'' ({{lang|mi|moko}} specialists) used a range of ''{{lang|mi|uhi}}'' (chisels) made from [[albatross]] bone which were [[hafting|hafted]] onto a handle, and struck with a mallet.{{cite journal |last=Best |first=Eldson |year=1904 |title=The Uhi-Maori, or Native Tattooing Instruments |journal=The Journal of the Polynesian Society |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=166–72 |url=http://www.jps.auckland.ac.nz/document/Volume_13_1904/Volume_13,_No._3,_September_1904/The_Uhi-Maori_or_native_tattooing_instruments,_by_Elsdon_Best,_p166-172/p1 }} The pigments were made from the {{lang|mi|[[awheto]]}} for the body colour, and ''{{lang|mi|ngarehu}}'' (burnt timbers) for the blacker face colour. The soot from burnt [[gum-digger|kauri gum]] was also mixed with fat to make pigment.{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/1966/K/KauriGum/MaoriUses/en |title=Kauri gum |publisher=[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] |accessdate=28 August 2015 }} The pigment was stored in ornate vessels named ''{{lang|mi|oko}}'', which were often buried when not in use. The ''{{lang|mi|oko}}'' were handed on to successive generations. A {{lang|mi|[[kōrere]]}} (feeding funnel) is believed to have been used to feed men whose mouths had become swollen from receiving {{lang|mi|tā moko}}.{{cite web |title=Korere - Tasman District |url=http://whenuaviz.landcareresearch.co.nz/place/73043 |publisher=Landcare Research - Manaaki Whenua |accessdate=21 March 2014 }} Men were predominantly the {{lang|mi|tā moko}} specialists, although [[Michael King|King]] records a number of women during the early 20th century who also took up the practice. There is also a remarkable account of a woman prisoner-of-war in the 1830s who was seen putting moko on the entire back of the wife of a chief.{{cn|date=January 2017}} ==Changes== The {{lang|mi|[[pākehā]]}} practice of collecting and trading ''{{lang|mi|[[mokomokai]]}}'' (tattooed heads) changed the dynamic of {{lang|mi|tā moko}} in the early colonial period. King (see below) talks about changes which evolved in the late 19th century when needles came to replace the ''{{lang|mi|uhi}}'' as the main tools. This was a quicker method, less prone to possible health risks, but the feel of the {{lang|mi|tā moko}} changed to smooth. {{lang|mi|Tā moko}} on men stopped around the 1860s in line with changing fashion and acceptance by {{lang|mi|Pākehā}}. Women continued receiving {{lang|mi|moko}} through the early 20th century,{{cite news |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=WH19041010.2.55&srpos=9&e=-------10--1----0tattoo+chin+women-- |title=A Relic of Barbarism |work=[[Wanganui Herald]] |date=1904 }} and the historian [[Michael King]] in the early 1970s interviewing over 70 elderly women who would have been given the {{lang|mi|moko}} before the 1907 [[Tohunga Suppression Act 1907|Tohunga Suppression Act]].{{cite web |url=http://teaohou.natlib.govt.nz/journals/teaohou/issue/Mao73TeA/c19.html |title=Moko |first=Michael |last=King |authorlink=Michael King |date=July 1973 |work=Te Ao Hou The Māori Magazine }}{{cite web|last1=Smale|first1=Aaron|title=Ta Moko|url=https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/ta-moko/|website=New Zealand Geographic|accessdate=4 May 2017}} Women were traditionally only tattooed on their lips, around the chin, and sometimes the nostrils.{{cite news |title=Is Permanent Makeup Worth It? |url=https://pinkycloud.com/permanent-makeup-the-pros-and-cons-of-tattooing-of-lips-eyelids-and-eyebrows-tattoo-prices |accessdate=16 February 2016 |work=Pinky Cloud |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150805024648/http://pinkycloud.com/permanent-makeup-the-pros-and-cons-of-tattooing-of-lips-eyelids-and-eyebrows-tattoo-prices/ |archivedate=5 August 2015 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.thetattoocollection.com/history_of_tattoos.htm |title=History of Tattoos |publisher=TheTattooCollection.com |accessdate=28 August 2015 }} =={{Lang|mi|Tā moko}} today== Since 1990 there has been a resurgence in the practice of {{lang|mi|tā moko}} for both men and women, as a sign of [[cultural identity]] and a reflection of the general revival of the [[Māori language|language]] and [[Māori culture|culture]]. Most {{lang|mi|tā moko}} applied today is done using a tattoo machine, but there has also been a revival of the use of ''{{lang|mi|uhi}}'' (chisels).{{Cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10484537 |title=Revival of Moko |date=29 December 2007 |work=[[New Zealand Herald]] }} Women too have become more involved as practitioners, such as Christine Harvey of the [[Chatham Islands|Chathams]], Henriata Nicholas in [[Rotorua]] and Julie Kipa in [[Whakatane]]. {{lang|mi|[[Te Uhi a Mataora]]}} was established in 2000 "to preserve, enhance, and develop tā moko as a living art form".{{cite web|title=Te Uhi a Mataora|url=http://www.maoriart.org.nz/committees.html|website=Toi Māori Aotearoa|publisher=Toi Māori Aotearoa|accessdate=3 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407201032/http://www.maoriart.org.nz/committees.html|archivedate=7 April 2017|df=}} File:MaoriMoko.png|Māori ''Moko'' in 1908 File:Tame Iti at gallery opening 13 October 2009.jpg|[[Tūhoe]] activist [[Tame Iti]] File:Tukukino, by Lindauer.jpg|Tukukino Te Ahiātaewa ([[Ngāti Tamaterā]]) File:TeAhoGoldie1905.jpg|Te Aho-o-te-rangi Wharepu ([[Ngāti Mahuta]]) ===Use by non-Māori=== Europeans were aware of {{Lang|mi|tā moko}} from at the time of the [[first voyage of James Cook]], and early Māori visitors to Europe, such as Moehanga in 1805,[http://rsnz.natlib.govt.nz/volume/rsnz_15/rsnz_15_00_006010.html ''"...the first Maori who reached England...had a well tattooed face..."''] then [[Hongi Hika]] in 1820 and [[Te Pēhi Kupe]] in 1826,{{cite web|url=http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/RobMoko-fig-RobMoko015a.html|title=Fig. 10.—Tattooing on the face of {{lang|mi|Te Pehi Kupe|nocat=y}}, drawn by himself|publisher=|accessdate=28 August 2015}} all had full-face {{Lang|mi|moko}}, as did several "[[Pākehā Māori]]" such as [[Barnet Burns]]. However, until relatively recently the art had little global impact. Appropriation of {{Lang|mi|tā moko}} by non-Māori is deemed offensive,{{cite web |url=http://wiki.bmezine.com/index.php/Moko |title=Moko }}{{cite web |url=http://www.tao-of-tattoos.com/kirituhi.html |title=Kirituhi - Moko Inspired }} and high-profile uses of Māori designs by [[Robbie Williams]], [[Ben Harper]] and a 2007 [[Jean-Paul Gaultier]] fashion show were controversial.{{Cite web |url=http://www.nzartmonthly.co.nz/kassem_001.html |title=Contemporary Manifestations of the traditional Ta Moko |last=Kassem |first=Mia |date=March 2003 |website=NZArtMonthly |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224051959/http://www.nzartmonthly.co.nz/kassem_001.html |archive-date=2011-02-24}}{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/fashion/44467 |title=Cheeky French steal moko |date=13 September 2007 |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA0608/S00054.htm |title=Sharples: Protected Objects Third Reading Speech |work=[[Scoop (website)|Scoop]] |accessdate=28 August 2015 }}{{Cite news|url=http://tattoo.about.com/cs/articles/a/maori_tamoko.htm|title=Why Most People Shouldn't Get Ta Moko Maori Tattoos|work=About.com Style|access-date=2017-05-03}} To reconcile the demand for Māori designs in a culturally sensitive way, the {{lang|mi|Te Uhi a Mataora}} group promotes the use of the term ''{{lang|mi|kirituhi}}'',{{cite press release|title=Ta Moko - A History On Skin|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0507/S00107.htm|accessdate=3 May 2017|publisher=Christchurch Arts Festival 2005|date=13 July 2005|via=[[Scoop Independent News]]}} which has now gained wide acceptance:{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3532027 |title=Moko 'exploitation' causes concern |date=3 November 2003 |agency=[[NZPA]] |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10563758 |title=Ta Moko making its mark on Maori |last=Ihaka |first=James |date=27 March 2009 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/167499 |title=Myth and the moko |work=[[Waikato Times]] |accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Cheseman|first1=Janelle|title=The resurrection of tā moko raises questions for Maori|url=http://www.newswire.co.nz/2014/03/resurrection-ta-moko-raises-questions-maori/|accessdate=3 May 2017|publisher=Newswire|date=15 March 2014}}
...{{lang|mi|Kirituhi}} translates literally to mean—"drawn skin." As opposed to {{lang|mi|Moko}} which requires a process of consents, genealogy and historical information, {{lang|mi|Kirituhi}} is merely a design with a {{lang|mi|Maori}} flavour that can be applied anywhere, for any reason and on anyone...
==Gallery== {{Clear}} File:TawhiaoNLA.jpg|[[Tāwhiao|Tāwhiao, Tukaroto Matutaera Potatau Te Wherowhero]] File:Barnet Burns.jpg|[[Barnet Burns]], a [[Pākehā Māori]] File:RiperataKahutia.jpg|[[Riperata Kahutia]] ([[Te Aitanga-a-Mahaki]]) File:RewiManiapoto1879.jpg|[[Rewi Maniapoto]] ([[Ngāti Maniapoto]]) File:Susan, Rotorua, New Zealand, ca. 1905.jpg|Guide Susan File:TamatiWakaNene1870s.jpg|[[Tāmati Wāka Nene]] ([[Ngāpuhi]]) File:Chef Maori1998-3157-173.jpg|Tomika Te Mutu, ([[Ngāi Te Rangi]]) File:Arthur James Iles - Tuterei Karewa of the Ngatimaru tribe, North Island, New Zealand - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Tuterei Karewa]], ([[Ngāti Maru (Hauraki)]]) File:American Photographic Company (Auckland) - Mrs Rabone - Google Art Project.jpg|Mrs. Rabone, 1871 File:Femme Maori Hariota Hull 1964-9530-173.jpg|Hariota Hull File:Femme Maori avec un tatouage au menton 1998-3173-139.jpg| File:Chef Maori au taiaha 1998-23059-173.jpg| File:Homme maori au visage tatoué.jpg| File:Femme Maori 1998-23050-173.jpg| File:Femme Maori 1998-3160-173.jpg| File:Femme Maori 1998-23052-173.jpg| File:Chef Maori 1998-23049-173.jpg| ==See also== * {{lang|mi|[[Mokomokai]]}}, preserved Māori heads * {{lang|sm|[[Pe'a]]}}, traditional male [[Samoans|Samoan]] tattoo ==References== {{reflist|2}} ===Sources=== * {{Cite book|title=The Coming of the Maori|last=Hīroa|first=Te Rangi|publisher=Whitcombe & Tombs|year=1951|isbn=|location=Wellington|pages=|author-link=Te Rangi Hīroa|ref=harv}} * Jahnke, R. and H. T., "The politics of Māori image and design", ''Pukenga Korero'' (Raumati (Summer) 2003), vol. 7, no. 1, pp. 5–31. * [[Michael King|King, M.]], and [[Marti Friedlander|Friedlander, M.]], (1992). ''Moko: Māori Tattooing in the 20th Century.'' (2nd ed.) Auckland: David Bateman. {{ISBN|1-86953-088-8}} * Nikora, L. W., Rua, M., and Te Awekotuku, Ng., "Wearing Moko: Māori Facial Marking in Today's World", in Thomas, N., Cole, A., and Douglas, B. (eds.), ''Tattoo. Bodies, Art and Exchange in the Pacific and the West'', London: Reacktion Books, pp. 191–204. * [[Horatio Gordon Robley|Robley, Maj-Gen H. G.]], (1896). ''[http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-RobMoko.html Moko, or Maori Tattooing].'' digital edition from New Zealand Electronic Text Centre * Te Awekotuku, Ngahuia, "Tā Moko: Māori Tattoo", in ''Goldie'', (1997) exhibition catalogue, Auckland: Auckland City Art Gallery and David Bateman, pp. 108–114. * Te Awekotuku, Ngahuia, "More than Skin Deep", in Barkan, E. and Bush, R. (eds.), ''Claiming the Stone: Naming the Bones: Cultural Property and the Negotiation of National and Ethnic Identity'' (2002) Los Angeles: Getty Press, pp. 243–254. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://www.tepapa.govt.nz/discover-collections/read-watch-play/maori/ta-moko-maori-tattoos-history Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa Online Resources on Moko] * [http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/search.aspx?term=moko&imagesonly=on Images relating to moko from the collection of the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa] * [http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-corpus-moko.html New Zealand Electronic Text Centre collection on Ta Moko, mokamokai, Horatio Robley and his art. A bibliography provides further links to other online resources.] * [https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-19628418 The rise of the Maori tribal tattoo], ''[[BBC News Magazine]]'', 21 September 2012, [[Ngahuia Te Awekotuku]], [[University of Waikato]], New Zealand {{DEFAULTSORT:Ta Moko}} [[Category:Māori art]] [[Category:Māori culture]] [[Category:Māori words and phrases]] [[Category:Polynesian tattooing]]

revision.text:
{{Semiotics}} In [[semiotics]], the '''value''' of a [[sign (semiotics)|sign]] depends on its position and relations in the system of signification and upon the particular [[code (Semiotics)|codes]] being used.
==Saussure's value==
[[File:Semiotic Value.GIF|thumb|left|the internal, vertical relationship between signifier and signified is distinct from the horizontal relation of values between signs.]]
Value is the sign as it is determined by the other signs in a semiotic system. For linguist [[Ferdinand de Saussure]], for example, the content of a sign in linguistics is ultimately determined and delimited not by its internal content, but by what surrounds it: the synonyms ''redouter'' ("to dread"), ''craindre'' ("to fear"), and ''avoir peur'' ("to be afraid") have their particular values because they exist in opposition to one another. If two of the terms disappeared, then the remaining sign would take on their roles, become vaguer, less articulate, and lose its "extra something" because it would have nothing to distinguish itself from.
For de Saussure, this suggests that thought is a chaotic nebula until linguistic structure dissects it and holds its divisions in equilibriums. This is akin to the philosophy of [[Sir William Hamilton, 9th Baronet|Sir William Hamilton]], who indirectly influenced Saussure<ref>[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/the_tls/article2869724.ece The Poet who could Smell Vowels]</ref> and believed that the mind could only grasp an idea through distinguishing it from something that it is not. He reasoned that the two objects would otherwise collapse together for the mind and become indistinguishable from one another.
Value determines the sign as a whole, not just meaning. Sound is also an indeterminate nebulous. The arbitrary nature of the sign and the flexibility of sound means that an agreed upon contrast is required. For example, "zena" is useful because it stands in contrast to "zenb" within an agreed upon system. Without the distinction, "zena" could be used for absolutely anything, or indeed nothing, making communication an impossibility.
It must also be noted that it is only the sign as a whole that has value. Linguistic structure simultaneously unites sound with thought and decomposes "thought-sound" into linguistic units, or signs, consisting of a signifier and a signified (sound-pattern and concept, respectively). When analysed in isolation, the sound-pattern or concept are pure differences, emerging from series of sound-patterns or concepts that they themselves are dependent upon. But in isolation, they are mere abstractions, because neither can exist without the connection between the two. It is the sign as a whole, then, that is the concrete entity of structural linguistics, which is not a pure difference, a negative term, but a pure value, a positive term that is merely in opposition or resistance to all the other signs in the system.
== Definitions == === Saussure === Drawing from the original definition proposed by [[Ferdinand de Saussure|Saussure]] (1857–1913), a sign has two parts: *as a ''signifier'', i.e. it will have a form that a person can see, touch, smell, and/or hear, and *as the ''signified'', i.e. it will represent an idea or mental construct of a ''thing'' rather than the thing itself.
This emphasises that the sign is merely a [[symbol]] for the [[class (philosophy)|class]] of [[object (philosophy)|object]] referred to. Hence, the [[lexical (Semiotics)|lexical]] word or noun "box" evokes a range of possibility from cheap card to gold-encrusted container. The reader or [[audience]] may not be able to see the particular box referred to but will be aware of its likely form from the other signs accompanying the use of the particular word.
However, there is no necessary connection between the signifier and the signified. There is nothing inherently ''boxy'' about the component sounds or letters that comprise the noun "box"—the scope of [[onomatopoeia]] is limited when forming a [[language]]. All that is necessary is that the relevant group of people should decide to use that word to [[denotation (Semiotics)|denote]] the object. Evidence that this is the correct view comes from the fact that each language can encode signifiers with whichever signified they wish to communicate. Hence, for example, the letters comprising "air" signify what humans breathe in English, and what fish breathe in Malay, i.e. water.
This makes a system of signs a very flexible mechanism for communicating [[Meaning (semiotics)|meaning]], but one which is conditioned by [[history]] and [[culture]], i.e. once a sign acquires a commonly accepted meaning in each language, it cannot arbitrarily be changed by any one person, but it is able to change [[Historical linguistics|diachronically]].
Further, [[Roman Jakobson]] (1896–1982) proposes that when a group of signs is used, there is an emotive function that reflects the speaker's attitude to the topic of his or her [[discourse]]. Language and the other coding systems are the means whereby one self-aware individual communicates with another. By selecting particular signs and placing them in a context, the addresser is making a [[cognitive]] use of the sign system to refer to his or her own social, moral, ethical, political or other values.
=== Barthes === Because signs may have multiple meanings, a sign can only be interpreted in its context. Saussure believed that any one sign takes its value from its position and relations with other signs within the linguistic system. Modern semiotics draws its inspiration from the work of, ''inter alios'', [[Roland Barthes]] (1915–1980), who argued that semiotics should expand its scope and concern: "...any system of signs, whatever their substance and limits; images, gestures, musical sounds, objects, and the complex associations of all of these, which form the content of ritual, convention or public entertainment: these constitute, if not languages, at least systems of signification" (1967, 9).
In the system to be interrogated, the relations will be both weak and strong, positive and negative, qualitative and quantitative, etc. In this, a sign cannot be attributed a value outside its context (although what is signified may have [[connotation (Semiotics)|connotative]] meaning(s) that resonate outside the context), and what is ''not'' present can be just as significant as what is present.
In a slightly different context of critique through the ''archaeological'' and ''genealogical'' methods for the study of [[knowledge]], [[Michel Foucault]] (1926–1984) used the idea of [[discontinuity (Postmodernism)|discontinuity]] as a means to ''revalorise'' elements of knowledge. In this, he considered the silences and lacunae within a text to be as significant as express statements. In both systems, the specific processes of analysis examine these gaps to reveal whose interests are served by the omissions. Such analysis is particularly useful to identify which questions are left unasked.
==Methods== The [[commutation test (Semiotics)|commutation test]] can be used to identify which signifiers are significant. The test depends on substitution: a particular signifier is chosen, then the effect of substituting alternatives is considered to determine the extent to which the value of the sign is changed. This both illuminates the meaning of the original choice and identifies the [[paradigms]] and [[code (Semiotics)|code]] to which the signifiers used belong.
[[Paradigmatic analysis]] compiles a list of the signifiers present in the text. This set comprises the paradigm. The analyst then compares and contrasts the set with absent signifiers, i.e. with other signifiers that might have been chosen. This reveals the significance of the choices made which might have been required because of technical production constraints or the limitations of the individual’s own technique, or because of the [[Trope (linguistics)|tropes]], generic [[Convention (norm)|conventions]], [[stylistics (linguistics)|style]] and [[rhetoric]]al purpose of the work. The analysis of paradigmatic relations helps to define the ‘value’ of specific items in a system.
==References== <references/> *Barthes, Roland ([1964] 1967). ''Elements of Semiology''. (Translated by Annette Lavers & Colin Smith). London: Jonathan Cape. *Saussure, Ferdinand de (1922). ''Cours de Linguistique Générale''. (Compiled by Bally & Séchehaye from notebooks of Saussure's students 1907-11).
[[Category:Semiotics]] [[Category:Linguistics]]

{{Redirect|Villa dei Misteri|the Pompeiian wine|Villa dei Misteri (wine)}}
[[File:Villa of the Mysteries in Pompeii.jpg|thumb|300px|Villa of the Mysteries in Pompeii seen from above]] [[File:Eschebach_%C3%9Cbersicht_Pompeji_150dpi.png|thumb|Location (top left) within Pompeii]] [[Image:Fresque des mytères, Pompéi.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A wall of the [[triclinium]], traditionally interpreted to represent the stages of initiation to the cult]] [[Image:Roman_fresco_Villa_dei_Misteri_Pompeii_009.jpg|thumb|Fresco depicting a [[Bacchus|Bacchian rite]]]] [[Image:Roman fresco Villa dei Misteri Pompeii 001.jpg|thumb|Fresco depicting the reading of the rituals of the bridal mysteries]] The '''Villa of the Mysteries''' ({{lang-it|Villa dei Misteri}}) is a well-preserved suburban [[Roman villa]] on the outskirts of [[Pompeii]], southern [[Italy]], famous for the series of [[fresco]]s in one room, which are usually thought to show the initiation of a young woman into a [[Greco-Roman mysteries|Greco-Roman mystery cult]]. These are now probably the best known of the relatively rare survivals of [[Ancient Roman painting]]. Like the rest of the Roman city of Pompeii, the villa was buried in the [[eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79]] and excavated from 1909 onwards (long after much of the main city). It is now a popular part of tourist visits to Pompeii, and forms part of the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] at Pompeii.
==Overview== Although covered with metres of ash and other volcanic material, the villa sustained only minor damage in the eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius|Vesuvius]] in 79 AD, and the majority of its walls, ceilings, and most particularly its frescoes survived largely undamaged. Since its excavation the roofing and other parts of the house have been maintained as necessary.
The Villa is named for the paintings in one room of the residence. This space may have been a [[triclinium]], and is decorated with very fine [[fresco]]es, believed to be painted in the early-middle 1st century.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Diotima|url = http://www.stoa.org/diotima/essays/seaford.shtml|website = www.stoa.org|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref> Although the actual subject of the frescoes is hotly debated, the most common interpretation of the images is scenes of the initiation of a woman into a [[Dionysian Mysteries|special cult of Bacchus]], a [[mystery cult]]<ref>[[Antonio Virgili]], Culti misterici ed orientali a Pompei, Gangemi, Roma, 2008</ref> that required specific rites and rituals to become a member. One of the defining features that help identify this as a Bacchian-related mural is the depiction of [[maenad]]s, the female followers of Bacchus. These devotees are often depicted dancing with swirling drapery and were found first on Greek pottery, many of which were made before the cult spread to Italy.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Villa of the Mysteries Pompeii by Raichel Le Goff|url = http://www.raichel.org/articlesRaichel/Art-Research/N-vases.htm|website = www.raichel.org|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref> Of all other interpretations, the most notable is that of [[Paul Veyne]], who believes that it depicts a young woman undergoing the rites of [[marriage]].
Though often believed to be a triclinium, the room with the frescoes could have also been a [[wikt:cubiculum|cubiculum]] of the matriarch, which would indicate that the matriarch was a member of the cult.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Pompeii.html|url = http://umich.edu/~kelseydb/Publications/spring2000/pompeii.html|website = umich.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-19}}</ref>
The Villa had both very fine rooms for dining and entertaining and more functional spaces. A wine-press was discovered when the Villa was excavated and has been restored in its original location. It was not uncommon for the homes of the very wealthy to include areas for the production of wine, olive oil, or other agricultural products, especially since many elite Romans owned farmland or orchards in the immediate vicinity of their villas.
The Villa may be easily accessed from Pompeii, lying some 400 metres northwest of the town walls, separated from it by a road with funerary monuments on either side. The Villa of the Mysteries was a suburban villa (Latin: ''villa suburbana'') with a close relationship to the city but not of it.
The ownership of the Villa is unknown, as is the case with many private homes in the city of Pompeii. However, certain artifacts give tantalizing clues. A bronze seal found in the villa names L. Istacidius Zosimus, a [[freedman]] of the powerful Istacidii family. Scholars have proposed him as the owner of the Villa or overseer of reconstruction after the [[62 Pompeii earthquake|earthquake of 62]]. The presence of a statue of [[Livia]], wife of [[Augustus]], has caused some historians to instead declare her to have been the owner.
As in other areas of [[Pompeii]] and [[Herculaneum]], a number of bodies were found in this villa, and [[plaster-of-Paris]] casts were made of them.
==Interpretation of the Frescoes== There are many different interpretations of the frescoes, but they are commonly believed to depict a [[mystery religion|religious rite]]. Another common theory is that the frescoes depict a bride initiating into the [[Dionysian Mysteries|Bacchian Mysteries]] in preparation for marriage. In this hypothesis, the elaborate costume worn by the main figure is believed to be wedding apparel.<ref name=":0" />
Based on the subject matter and order of each fresco, they are intended to be read as a single narrative. Women and satyrs are featured prominently. Because of the widely accepted theory of the mural depicting an initiation from the cult of [[Bacchus]], some think that the room with the frescoes was used to conduct rituals and celebrations related to the god.<ref name=":0" />
* The first mural shows a noble Roman woman (possibly the initiate's mother, who can cross no further) approaching a priestess or matron seated on a throne, by which stands a small boy reading a scroll – presumably the declaration of the initiation. On the other side of the throne the young initiate is shown in a purple robe and [[Myrtle (plant)|myrtle]] crown, holding a sprig of [[lauraceae|laurel]] and a tray of cakes. She appears to have been transformed into a serving girl, but may be bringing an offering to the god or goddess.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries">{{cite web|title=Dionysian Mysteries|url=http://www.mlahanas.de/Greeks/LX/DionysianMysteries.html|website=www.hellenica.de|accessdate=15 November 2014}}</ref> * The second mural depicts another priestess (or senior initiate) and her assistants preparing the ''[[liknon]]'' basket; at her feet are mysterious mushroom-shaped objects. At one side a ''[[Silenus|sileni]]'' (a horse element) is playing a [[lyre]]. ([[Silenus]] was the tutor and companion of [[Bacchus]].)<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/> * The third mural shows a [[satyr]] playing the [[panpipe]]s and a [[nymph]] suckling a goat, in an [[Arcadia (utopia)|Arcadian scene]]. To their right, the initiate is in a panic. This is the last time we see her for a few scenes; when she appears again, she has changed. Some scholars think ''[[katabasis]]'' has occurred.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/> * In the direction to which she stares in horror, another mural shows a young satyr being offered a bowl of wine by Silenus while behind him, another satyr holds up a frightening mask which the drinking satyr sees reflected in the bowl (this may parallel the mirror into which young Bacchus stares in the [[Orphic Mysteries|Orphic rites]]). Next to them sits a goddess, ([[Ariadne]] or [[Semele]]), with Bacchus lying across her lap.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/> * The next mural shows the initiate returning. She now carries a staff and wears a cap, items often presented after the successful completion of an initiation ordeal. She kneels before the priestess, and appears to be whipped by a winged female figure. Next to her is a dancing figure (a [[Maenad]] or [[Thyiad]]) and a gowned figure with a [[thyrsus]] (an initiation symbol of Bacchus) made of long stalks of wrapped fennel, with a pine cone on top.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/> * In her penultimate appearance we see her being prepared with new clothes, while [[Eros (mythology)|Cupid]] holds up a mirror to her. After this scene, there is another image of Cupid.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/> * Finally, the initiate is shown enthroned and in an elaborate costume. This is all we know of the Roman rites of initiation.<ref name="Dionysian Mysteries"/><ref>Linda Fierz-David, Katherine Bradway, Nor Hall, and [[Mary Beard (classicist)|Mary Beard]] and others have interpreted these murals.</ref><ref>http://www.art-and-archaeology.com/timelines/rome/empire/vm/villaofthemysteries.html</ref>
== See also == {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Roman fresco Villa dei Misteri Pompeii 008.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/dionysiac-frieze-villa-of-the-mysteries.html Dionysiac frieze, Villa of Mystsdaasdaseries, Pompeii], [[Smarthistory]]<ref name="smarth">{{cite web | title =Dionysiac frieze, Villa of Mysteries, Pompeii | work = | publisher =[[Smarthistory]] at [[Khan Academy]] | date = | url =http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/dionysiac-frieze-villa-of-the-mysteries.html | accessdate =February 20, 2013 }}</ref> }} *[[Roman architecture]] *[[List of Roman domes]] *[[Pompei Scavi-Villa dei Misteri (Circumvesuviana station)|Pompei Scavi-Villa dei Misteri railway station]]
== Videos ==
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XR3ejPZifRA] von [[Stefan F. Wirth]]
== References ==
{{reflist}} *{{cite book|first=Claudia |last=Converto |title=Campania, civilisation and art|publisher=Kina Italia|location=Milan}}
== External links == {{commonscat|Villa of the Mysteries (Pompeii)}} * [http://www.archaeology.org/issues/124-1403/features/1813-pompeii-saving-the-villa-of-the-mysteries Preservation of the Villa featured on archaeology.org] *[http://www.art-and-archaeology.com/timelines/rome/empire/vm/villaofthemysteries.html Villa of the Mysteries on www.art-and-archaeology.com] * [http://creadm.solent.ac.uk/custom/rwpainting/cover/index.html Romano-Campanian Wall-Painting (English, Italian, Spanish and French introduction)]

{{Infobox artist | name = Edouard Cortès | image = Don Kurtz - Edouard Cortes.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Edouard Cortès as a young man | birth_name = | birth_date = 6 August 1882 | birth_place = {{flagicon|France}} [[Lagny-sur-Marne|Lagny/Marne]], [[France]] | death_date = November 26, 1969 (aged 87) | death_place = {{flagicon|France}} [[Lagny-sur-Marne|Lagny/Marne]], [[France]] | nationality = {{flagicon|France}} [[France|French]] | field = [[Cityscape]]s, [[Paris]] | training = His father [[Antonio Cortès]], [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in [[Paris]] | movement = [[Post-Impressionism]] | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Edouard Léon Cortès''' (1882–1969) was a [[French people|French]] [[Post-impressionism|post-impressionist]] artist of French and [[Spanish people|Spanish]] ancestry. He is known as "Le Poete Parisien de la Peinture" or "the Parisian Poet of Painting" because of his diverse Paris cityscapes in a variety of weather and night settings.
== Personal life == Cortes was born on August 6, 1882, in [[Lagny-sur-Marne]], about twenty miles east of [[Paris]]. His father, Antonio Cortés, had been a painter for the [[Spanish monarchy|Spanish Royal Court]].
In 1914 Cortès married Fernande Joyeuse, with whom he had a daughter in 1916.
Although Cortès was a [[pacifist]], when war came close to his native village he was compelled to enlist in a French Infantry Regiment at the age of 32. As a contact agent Cortès was wounded by a bayonet, evacuated to a military hospital, and awarded the [[Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de Guerre]]. After recovery he was the reassigned to use his artistic talent to sketch enemy positions. Later in life his convictions led him to refuse the [[Légion d'Honneur]] from the French Government. In 1919 he was demobilized.
His wife had died in 1918 and he soon married his sister-in-law Lucienne Joyeuse.
Cortès lived a simple life amid a close circle of friends. He died on November 28, 1969, in Lagny, and has a street named in his honor. <ref name="Klein"/>
== Painting history == At the age of 17, Edouard began his studies at the [[École des Beaux-Arts]] in Paris. His first exhibition in 1901 brought him immediate recognition. Cortès stressed his independence. Once, in responding to a journalist who asked if he was a student of [[Luigi Loir]], he replied in pun: "Non, seul élève de moi-même." ("No, a student of myself only.")
His works were first exhibited in North America in 1945 and he subsequently achieved even greater success. In his last year of life he was awarded the prestigious [[Prix Antoine-Quinson]] from the [[Salon de Vincennes]]. <ref name="Klein">{{cite book | last = Klein | first = David | title = Edouard Cortès, Le Poète Parisien de la Peinture | publisher = Klein Art Gallery | year = 1999 | location = Hong Kong | isbn = 0-9672343-0-1 |language=fr}}</ref> <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image: edouard_leon_cortes_b1250_place_st_michel_notre_dame_wm.jpg|thumb|left|350px|''Place St. Michel, Notre Dame'', 1955, www.urbanimpressionist.com.]] -->
== Lost and stolen paintings == On November 30, 2000, four paintings by Cortès were recovered in [[Kalispell, Montana]], following an eight-month investigation conducted by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]'s [[San Francisco]] Division. The recovered paintings were stolen in 1988 during a burglary at the Simic Gallery in [[Carmel, California]].<ref name="FBI">{{cite web|last=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] Theft Notices & Recoveries |title=FBI — Art Theft Program |url=https://www.fbi.gov/hq/cid/arttheft/northamerica/us/cortes/cortes.htm |accessdate=2007-05-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509090457/http://www.fbi.gov/hq/cid/arttheft/northamerica/us/cortes/cortes.htm |archivedate=May 9, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2008, a lost Cortès painting of a Paris street scene was discovered amongst donated items at a [[Goodwill Industries]] thrift store in [[Easton, Maryland]]. After an alert store manager noticed that it was a signed original, the painting was subsequently auctioned for $40,600 (US) at [[Sotheby's]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Easton Team Scores Big!|year=2008|publisher=Goodwill Connection|issue=II|page=8}}</ref>
